messages.content: What are the four temperaments in the CS Joseph framework?

Guardians, Artisans, Intellectuals, and Idealists. These come straight from Plato's Republic - the Greeks figured this shit out thousands of years ago. Guardians are your SJs, Artisans are SPs, Intellectuals are NTs, and Idealists are NFs. This isn't some modern psychology invention. It's about fundamental human nature and how your cognitive functions organize around different life philosophies.
Which types are Guardians?

ESTJ, ESFJ, ISTJ, and ISFJ. All the SJ types - sensing judgers. They make up 40% of the world's population, which is why society feels so damn structured around their values. Military, police, firefighters - those are Guardian strongholds. If you've ever felt like the world expects you to just follow the rules and do your duty, now you know why. Guardians run the show in most Western societies.
What does Si hero mean for Guardians?

Si hero for ISTJ and ISFJ means your entire world centers on past experience and memory. You live through what was. Your superpower is remembering details from years ago and using them to navigate the present. You're not trying new things for the hell of it - you need to know if something worked before. Duty drives you. What you should do always beats what you want to do. This makes you incredibly loyal and traditional, but also risk-averse as hell.
What's the difference between ESTJ and ESFJ?

Both are extroverted Guardians, but ESTJ leads with Te hero - rationale and metrics. They want to understand systems and make them efficient. ESFJ leads with Fe hero - ethics and care. They want everyone comfortable and the culture harmonious. ESTJ asks 'does this work and can I measure it?' ESFJ asks 'does everyone feel okay and are we all getting along?' Both use Si parent for duty and tradition, but they express Guardian values differently.
Why do Guardians focus so much on the past?

Because they all have Si - introverted sensing - in their ego. Either Si hero or Si parent. Si is literally about past experience and memory. Guardians don't trust the new and untested. They trust what worked before. You tell a Guardian to try something by showing them someone else did it successfully. Their entire decision-making process filters through 'have I seen this work?' This makes them stable and reliable, but also resistant to change.
What does it mean that Guardians are duty-based?

Guardians prioritize what they should do over what they want to do. Every single time. Si creates this sense of obligation - duty, responsibility, tradition. They're not asking 'what sounds fun?' They're asking 'what's expected of me?' This is why they dominate protective roles. Police, military, firefighters - all built on duty. The SJ temperament code literally means they judge based on sensing reality, and that reality says follow your obligations.
How does American culture favor Guardians?

American culture is massively SJ-biased. Structure, rules, tradition, duty - these are Guardian values baked into everything. When you don't fit the Guardian mold, society labels you. ADD, ADHD, autism diagnoses often hit intuitives and artisans who just don't operate like Guardians. The education system, workplace expectations, social norms - all designed around the 40% who are SJs. If you're an intuitive, you've felt this your entire life. You're not broken - you're just not a Guardian in a Guardian world.
What's the Guardian interaction with risk?

Guardians are risk-averse. Period. Si makes them cautious because they remember every time something went wrong. They judge people who take risks because those risks threaten safety and stability. If you're trying to get a Guardian on board with something new, show them proof it worked elsewhere. Don't sell them on possibility - that's Ne, their inferior or trickster. Sell them on precedent. Show them the safe path, and they'll walk it with you.
Why are Guardians called traditionalists?

Because they value what was over what could be. Si dominates their cognitive stack - either hero or parent position. Tradition isn't just nostalgia for Guardians. It's survival. If something worked in the past, it's safe. If it's new, it's dangerous until proven otherwise. They literally build society's traditions and then protect them. Family rituals, cultural practices, institutional rules - that's all Guardian energy maintaining continuity through time.
What careers attract Guardians?

Military, police, firefighting, nursing, teaching, administration - anything centered on protection, duty, and service. The phrase 'to serve and protect' is pure SJ philosophy. These aren't just jobs to Guardians - they're callings that align with their cognitive wiring. They need roles where responsibility is clear, tradition is respected, and their work protects others. Forty percent of the population funneling into these fields creates the backbone of societal stability.
How do ISTJ and ISFJ differ?

Both have Si hero - duty and memory drive them. But ISTJ has Te parent while ISFJ has Fe parent. ISTJ organizes through rationale and metrics. They want systems that make logical sense. ISFJ organizes through ethics and care. They want harmony and people feeling valued. ISTJ will tell you the efficient way. ISFJ will tell you the kind way. Both are incredibly loyal and responsible, but ISTJ leans systematic while ISFJ leans relational.
What does it mean that Guardians are sensors?

Sensors use sensing functions in their top two slots. For Guardians, that's Si - introverted sensing. They perceive reality through concrete experience, not abstract patterns. They trust what they can verify through their own past. This makes them 70% of the population when you combine SJs and SPs. Intuitives only make up 30%, which is why sensors sometimes think intuitives are weird. You're not weird - you're just using Ne or Ni instead of Se or Si to perceive the world.
Why do Guardians struggle with new experiences?

They don't struggle with new experiences - they struggle with untested risks. Si needs data from the past. If there's no precedent, there's no safety. You can get a Guardian to try something new by showing them someone else succeeded first. Their inferior Ne means possibilities feel threatening, not exciting. Where an intuitive sees potential, a Guardian sees danger. Once they try it and it goes well, Si files it away as safe. Then they'll do it again.
What's the role of Te in ESTJ and ISTJ?

Te - extraverted thinking - is about rationale, metrics, and understanding systems. For ESTJ, it's hero function. They lead with 'does this make logical sense and can I measure results?' For ISTJ, it's parent function. They use Te to organize their Si memories into efficient systems. Both types excel at creating and maintaining structures that work. They don't care about your feelings regarding the rules - they care if the rules produce results. Te plus Si creates the ultimate duty-bound efficiency machine.
What's the role of Fe in ESFJ and ISFJ?

Fe - extraverted feeling - is about ethics, culture, and making people feel accepted. For ESFJ, it's hero function. They lead with 'is everyone okay and do they feel cared for?' For ISFJ, it's parent function. They use Fe to ensure their Si traditions include and comfort others. Both types are the glue in social structures. They remember your birthday, check on you when you're down, and create the warm spaces where communities thrive. Fe plus Si means they protect people through care and duty combined.
How do Guardians view intuitives?

As weird, out of place, or not fitting in. Because intuitives are only 30% of the population in an SJ-dominated culture. When you're the 40% majority, everyone else looks abnormal. Guardians trust concrete reality and past experience. Intuitives trust abstract patterns and future possibilities. To a Guardian, that looks unstable or even reckless. It's not personal - it's cognitive function incompatibility. Si can't understand Ni or Ne dominance because those functions operate on completely different perception modes.
What does Guardian Fi child or Ti child mean?

ESTJ and ISTJ have Fi child - morals and personal values in the child slot. This means their morality is innocent and pure but also vulnerable. They want to feel valued and morally good. ESFJ and ISFJ have Ti child - logic and truth in the child slot. They want to feel smart and logically consistent but doubt their reasoning. The child function is your source of happiness but also insecurity. Guardians need validation in these areas - ESTJs and ISTJs for their worth, ESFJs and ISFJs for their intelligence.
Why do Guardians make up 40% of the population?

Because societies need stability to survive. Guardians provide that through duty, tradition, and protection. They're the ones who show up, follow through, and maintain the structures everyone else takes for granted. Evolutionary psychology suggests the SJ temperament became dominant because communities with strong Guardian presence thrived. They protect, they serve, they remember, they organize. Without that 40%, civilization collapses into chaos. The world needs Guardians more than any other temperament for basic societal function.
What's the Guardian relationship with loyalty?

Loyalty is everything to Guardians. Si creates long-term memory that never forgets who was there for them and who wasn't. They remember every favor, every betrayal, every moment of support. This makes them fiercely loyal to those who prove trustworthy and unforgiving to those who don't. Honor matters. Keeping your word matters. If you break trust with a Guardian, that memory stays in their Si forever. But earn their loyalty, and they'll protect you with everything they have. It's not conditional - it's eternal.
How do Guardians differ from Artisans?

Guardians are SJs - past focused through Si. Artisans are SPs - present focused through Se. Guardians ask what they should do based on duty and tradition. Artisans ask what they want to do based on immediate reality and experience. Guardians are risk-averse and judging. Artisans are risk-seeking and perceiving. Both are sensors, both concrete, but Guardians protect and preserve while Artisans perform and adapt. ESTJ versus ESTP shows this perfectly - one builds the system, one exploits it for results.
